docs.lead_paragraph: A British-American scientist and two Norwegians were awarded the prize for identifying the cells that help animals determine where they are.

headline.main: Nobel Prize in Medicine Is Awarded to Three Who Discovered Brain’s ‘Inner GPS’
headline.print_headline: Nobel Prize in Medicine Is Awarded to Three Who Discovered Brain’s ‘Inner GPS’

docs.abstract: John O'Keefe and couple May-Britt Moser and Edvard I Moser are awarded Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for discovering 'inner GPS in the brain' that enables virtually all creatures to navigate their surroundings; Mosers are only the second married couple to win a Nobel in medicine, and will share half of $1.1 million prize with O'Keefe.
docs.snippet: A British-American scientist and two Norwegians were awarded the prize for identifying the cells that help animals determine where they are.

docs.lead_paragraph: The first person diagnosed with Ebola in the United States was fighting for his life at a Dallas hospital on Sunday and appeared to be receiving none of the experimental medicines for the virus, a top U.S. health official said.

headline.main: Ebola Patient in Dallas Struggling to Survive, Says CDC Head
headline.print_headline: Ebola Patient in Dallas Struggling to Survive, Says CDC Head

docs.snippet: The first person diagnosed with Ebola in the United States was fighting for his life at a Dallas hospital on Sunday and appeared to be receiving none of the experimental medicines for the virus, a top U.S. health official said.

docs.lead_paragraph: In the first days of the Ebola outbreak in West Africa, as aid workers and health authorities battled to contain the deadly virus, Mariano Lugli asked himself a simple question: where was the World Health Organization?

headline.main: Aid Workers Ask Where Was WHO in Ebola Outbreak?
headline.print_headline: Aid Workers Ask Where Was WHO in Ebola Outbreak?

docs.snippet: In the first days of the Ebola outbreak in West Africa, as aid workers and health authorities battled to contain the deadly virus, Mariano Lugli asked himself a simple question: where was the World Health Organization?

docs.lead_paragraph: Each medical case, like each mushroom, is a diagnostic puzzle.
docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by pediatrician and internist Jonathan Reisman describes becoming interested in mycology and mushroom hunting; compares the hobby to his medical practice, and the many ways in which mushroom hunting is similar to diagnosing and treating illnesses.
docs.snippet: Each medical case, like each mushroom, is a diagnostic puzzle.

docs.lead_paragraph: To uncover patterns that might steer care, doctors and scientists are dipping into the medical records of thousands of patients.

headline.main: Can Big Data Tell Us What Clinical Trials Don’t?

docs.abstract: Veronique Greenwood Eureka column points out doctors and scientists are increasingly dipping into aggregated medical records of thousands or even millions of patients to uncover patterns that might help steer care; observes turning to enormous troves of data is replacement for large, costly and time-consuming clinical trials that are rarely carried out for uncommon medical complications.
docs.snippet: To uncover patterns that might steer care, doctors and scientists are dipping into the medical records of thousands of patients.

docs.lead_paragraph: His week began thousands of miles away with a frantic bid to save a life.

headline.main: Across 3 Continents, Ebola Makes Its Way to US
headline.print_headline: Across 3 Continents, Ebola Makes Its Way to US

docs.snippet: His week began thousands of miles away with a frantic bid to save a life.

docs.lead_paragraph: The World Health Organization has issued guidance in West Africa on collecting convalescent blood or plasma for transfusion, but there are obstacles.

headline.main: A Plan to Use Survivors’ Blood for Ebola Treatment in Africa
headline.print_headline: Health Officials Plan Use of Ebola Survivors’ Blood as a Treatment

docs.abstract: World Health Organization issues guidance on how to collect blood of people sickened by Ebola virus but who have since recovered, in effort to access antibodies that might help others fight off infection; treatment is not considered foolproof and there are many logistical problems in carrying this out in West Africa.
docs.snippet: The World Health Organization has issued guidance in West Africa on collecting convalescent blood or plasma for transfusion, but there are obstacles.

docs.lead_paragraph: Studies indicate that stress can be stimulating and healthy, and that boredom can have the same effects as having too much to do.

headline.main: The Contrarians on Stress: It Can Be Good for You
headline.print_headline: The Contrarians on Stress: It Can Be Good for You

docs.abstract: Alina Tugend Shortcuts column identifies three common misconceptions about stress, pointing out boredom can have same adverse effects as having too much to do.
docs.snippet: Studies indicate that stress can be stimulating and healthy, and that boredom can have the same effects as having too much to do.

headline.main: How to Stop the Spread of Ebola?

docs.abstract: What more could have been done, and should be done in the future, to contain the spread of a contagion like the Ebola virus, particularly with airline travel?
docs.snippet: What more could have been done, and should be done in the future, to contain the spread of a contagion like the Ebola virus, particularly with airline travel?

docs.lead_paragraph: In a program offering sexually active teenagers in St. Louis free birth control, pregnancy and abortion rates were less than a quarter of those of such teenagers nationally.

headline.main: A Study Bolsters a Call to Use Long-Acting Contraceptives
headline.print_headline: A Study Bolsters a Call to Use Long-Acting Contraceptives

docs.abstract: Study in New England Journal of Medicine examines results of program in St Louis that counseled teenage girls and provided them with free contraception, including long-acting methods like intrauterine devices and hormonal implants; relates that girls who participated in program had less than a quarter of the annual pregnancy, birth and abortion rates of teenage girls nationally.
docs.snippet: In a program offering sexually active teenagers in St. Louis free birth control, pregnancy and abortion rates were less than a quarter of those of such teenagers nationally.
